para.paratext: Both Fed. R. Evid. 701 and O.C.G.A. § 24-7-701 provide that a witness not testifying as an expert must limit the form of opinions or inferences to those which are (1) rationally based on the perception of the witness, (2) helpful to a clear understanding of the witness' testimony or the determination of a fact in issue, and (3) not based on scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge within the scope of Fed. R. Evid. 702. To be admissible, the opinions or inferences of a lay witness must not require any specialized knowledge, must be the type of opinions or inferences that an ordinary person could reach, and must be helpful to the fact finder.[1] A witness may not testify to a matter unless he has personal knowledge of the matter.[2] He will be presumed to be testifying from personal knowledge if nothing to the contrary appears.[3] He cannot state conclusions or beliefs not based on his firsthand knowledge.[4] When considering O.C.G.A. § 24-7-701, the courts will look to the decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court and the Eleventh Circuit since the statute is modeled on the federal rules.[5]

The Eleventh Circuit case United States v. Jayyousi[6] illustrates the court's interpretation of Federal Rule 701. In that case, “dirty-bomber” José Padilla and two co-defendants were convicted of providing material support to terrorists. At trial, government witness, FBI Agent John Kavanaugh offered lay opinion testimony about code words defendants used in telephone conversations whose wiretap transcripts were already admitted into evidence. Defendants contended that the agent could not form a rationally based perception about the meaning of words that were intercepted when he was not present. The court stated that it had held previously that testimony was “rationally based on the perception of the witness” in cases in which the witness did not himself create the document or participate in the activity about which he testified.[7] Additionally, the court found the agent's testimony helpful to the jury because his five-year investigation allowed him to provide context by connecting code words to defendants specific acts of support such as check and wire transfers and to make inferences the jurors could not readily draw on their own.[8] Finally, the court held that Agent Kavanaugh's testimony was not based on specialized knowledge because he limited it to inferences he made during the investigation rather than basing it on the knowledge he gained from years of experience in the field.[9]

Likewise, the Court of Appeals held that it was proper to admit lay opinion testimony regarding the fact that a defendant was driving while impaired, reasoning that the witnesses need not know whether the defendant had consumed alcohol or drugs, but could base their testimony on their observations of defendant's erratic driving which is consistent with someone who is intoxicated.[10] The Georgia Supreme Court has also allowed lay witness testimony as to the identification of a defendant in a security video and surveillance photos, where the video was of poor quality and the defendant's appearance had changed drastically since the time of the crime. The Court reasoned that the witnesses were better acquainted with the defendant, and thus were in a better position to identify defendant in the video.[11] Lay opinion testimony of witnesses regarding events that transpired during the day a victim was killed has also been allowed, even though the witnesses never saw the defendant shoot the victims.[12]

O.C.G.A. §§ 24-7-702 and 24-7-707 provide for the admissibility of expert testimony in civil and criminal cases. A party concerned about whether proposed expert testimony will conform to the statutory guidelines may move for a pretrial hearing under O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702(d).[13] The court must conduct a hearing during or before the final pretrial conference in the case.[14]

In Johnson v. Knebel,[15] the Georgia Supreme Court clarified the proper subjects and foundations for opinion testimony. Expert opinions can be based upon facts within the expert's personal knowledge or facts proved by other witnesses, but lay opinions must be based upon facts within the layman's personal knowledge.[16] Properly qualified expert witnesses may give opinion testimony on matters “the jury could not ordinarily determine for themselves.”[17] Lay witnesses may give opinion testimony when they cannot adequately describe their observations without stating their personal opinions.[18]

In Brown v. State,[19] the Georgia Court of Appeals found a victim's testimony inadmissible when the prosecutor asked the victim's opinion as to whether it appeared that the defendant's sword was in his control when he stabbed the victim, and the victim volunteered that he believed the defendant stabbed him on purpose. Likewise, lay opinion testimony regarding the speed of travel of a fire truck was found inadmissible where the witness's testimony lacked a proper foundation because she acknowledged that she had never been hit by a car traveling at that speed before, and her perception of the speed was formed solely from the force of the impact.[20] However the court did acknowledge that speed testimony is generally admissible opinion testimony.

In Carlock v. Kmart Corp,[21] a premises liability case in which the plaintiff alleged that defendant's negligent security measures led to a shooting, the court held that testimony about the foreseeability of the criminal act at issue was properly excluded because “[a] party may not bolster his case as to the ultimate issue with expert testimony when the jury could reach the same conclusion independently of the opinion of others.”[22]

However, if the witness has presented the data to the jury in such a way that the jury could draw the inference as well as the witness, then it is improper to let the witness state an opinion. Calloway v. Rossman, 150 Ga. App. 381, 257 S.E.2d 913 (1979).
A witness must testify from his own firsthand knowledge. Garrett v. State, 169 Ga. App. 327, 312 S.E.2d 621 (1983).

Upon motion of a party, the court may hold a pretrial hearing to determine whether the witness qualifies as an expert and whether the expert's testimony satisfies the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of his Code section. Such hearing and ruling shall be completed no later than the final pretrial conference contemplated under Code Section 9-11-16.

Application of statute governing admissibility of expert opinions in civil actions would not have changed trial court's ultimate, and correct, conclusion that defendant's motion in products liability action to exclude testimony of plaintiff's expert was without merit, as motion was filed several months after final pretrial conference had taken place, and statute required that a hearing and ruling on admissibility of expert testimony be completed no later than the final pretrial conference. Ford Motor Co. v. Gibson, 283 Ga. 398, 659 S.E.2d 346 (2008) (case addressed former O.C.G.A. 24-9-67.1, but pretrial conference provision of O.C.G.A. 9-11-16 remains the same).
